Award.AwardTitle: Confessional Reluctance and Ethics Enforcement: The Paradoxical Cost of Zero Tolerance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Description

In response to recent high profile ethical catastrophes, many organizations have adopted tougher ethical stances, the most extreme of which are "zero tolerance" policies, in which small infractions are substantially punished. Although punitive policies may reduce the base-rate of ethical violations, they may paradoxically increase major ethical infractions by discouraging employees' willingness to report violations. This phenomenon is referred to as confessional reluctance, defined as the resistance to disclosing ethical violations to peers and supervisors. Confessional reluctance could turn minor ethical violations into major ethical catastrophes, as organization members seek to cover-up their mistakes through deception, falsification of records, and other means. This research project will examine confessional reluctance across several studies with multiple methods, including archival, experimental and a real-world field study. This research is important because understanding and preventing organizational ethical catastrophes is essential to a functioning society. Ethical breaches take economic and social tolls among the general public, corporations and governments. By identifying a new way of understanding major ethical breaches, our research will suggest actionable strategies for decreasing them, including employee selection, improving work-team functioning, and implementing more proactive organizational ethical climates. Ultimately, this research will provide a straightforward and empirically-backed method for making organizations more ethical.

Technical Description

This project proposes a multilevel model linking punitive ethical climates, confessional reluctance and unethical escalation, and test it through archival, field and experimental studies. To better understand confessional reluctance - and to enable interventions to reduce it - this research also identify learning climate, team/lead-member exchange and prosocial motivation as key moderators of the punitiveness-confessional reluctance relationship. Study 1 provides preliminary evidence for confessional reluctance and its link to punitive ethical climates through an online survey. Studies 2, 3 and 4 examine the link between confessional reluctance, punitive ethical climate and the escalation of unethical behavior through experimental studies. Study 4 uses company annual reports to examine the link between punitive policies and major ethical infractions, and Study 5 provides a longitudinal test of the model in the field. This research extends the literature by combining organizational variables (i.e., climate) and individual variables (i.e., prosocial motivation) into a multilevel framework. Our approach harnesses the complementary strengths of different methodologies, including the control of the lab, the realism of archival studies, and the generalizability of field samples. The lab studies provide rigorous manipulations of punitive climate with realistic simulations of organizational behavior and behavioral measures of ethical violations and confessional reluctance. The archival study extends our model to a range of companies, and the longitudinal field study examines our full model across branches of a corporation. Our interdisciplinary approach uses the tools of organizational behavior and experimental social psychology to extend our understanding of ethical behavior. Our model is particularly transformative because it contradicts basic intuitions about management. An understandable reaction to ethical breaches is to make an ethical climate more punitive, but this can paradoxically make major ethical violations more likely. Therefore, this research suggests a concrete intervention for making organizations more ethical.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In response to recent high-profile ethical catastrophes, many organizations have adopted tougher ethical stances, the most extreme of which are “zero tolerance” policies, in which small infractions are substantially punished. Although punitive policies may reduce the base-rate of ethical violations, they may paradoxically increase major ethical infractions by discouraging employees’ willingness to report violations. We refer to this phenomenon as confessional reluctance, defined as the “resistance to disclosing ethical violations to peers and supervisors.” We hypothesized that confessional reluctance would turn minor ethical violations into major ethical catastrophes, as organization members seek to cover-up their mistakes through deception, falsification of records, and other means. We examined confessional reluctance across several studies with multiple methods, including observational survey research and longitudinal field studies.

Our studies provide clear support for the importance of confessional reluctance in the escalation of unethical behavior. They also reveal that confessional reluctance flourishes in zero-tolerance organizational climates, just as we had predicted. Specifically, we conducted two broad sets of studies: 1) survey studies using working adults throughout America and 2) a longitudinal field studies examining the (un)ethical behaviors of employees in a large real-world organization.

The survey studies revealed that employees do indeed express the reluctance to confess minor ethical infractions to their supervisor, and this is tied to the desire to cover-up additional unethical behavior. The longitudinal field studies reveal evidence that confessional reluctance is an essential link in the chain of unethical behavior in real organizations. Our two field studies reveal that organizations with a “zero-tolerance” ethical policy were more likely to have high confessional reluctance, and this in turn was likely to increase employees cover-up behavior.

This research on confessional reluctance possesses both clear intellectual merit and broader impacts. In terms of intellectual merit, this research identifies a previously unstudied phenomena that enables important theoretical synthesis throughout the fields of management, organizational behavior, social psychology, behavioral ethics, and sociology. Confessional reluctance provides a new lens for understanding unethical behavior in organizations, and the importance of considering dynamic processes (i.e. the influence of environment and behavior over time) when seeking to understand (un)ethical behavior.

This research has obvious broader impacts. Understanding and preventing organizational ethical catastrophes is essential to a functioning society. Ethical breaches take economic and social tolls among the general public, corporations and governments.  Importantly, this research reveals that the intuitions of business and governmental leaders may lead us astray when it comes to creating ethical organizations. On the surface, it would make sense that the best way to suppress unethical behavior is through zero-tolerance policies. While this may decrease the reporting of unethical behavior, these policies may not decrease actual unethical behavior. Moreover, once unethical behavior has been committed, zero-tolerance policies increase confessional reluctance and — as our study show — produce more cover-up behaviors which thereby facilitate escalation of unethical behavior

By identifying a new way of understanding unethical escalation, our research suggests actionable strategies for decreasing them—namely providing more forgiving ethical climates. Although this may seem counterintuitive in this “zero-tolerance” era, by building in a small buffer for minor ethical infractions, organizations can make coverups and the consequent large ethical catastrophes less likely. Ultimately, this research provides a straightforward and empirically-backed method for making organizations more ethical.
